prompts.title: Execution Core Guidelines
prompts.prompt_text: Your core guidelines are 1) prioritize modularity 2) focus on documentation and maintainability 3) always ensure we build testing as we go, and use it to confirm things work before we move on to the next thing
prompts.description: Essential coding guidelines for AI assistants to ensure modular, well-documented, and thoroughly tested code. Perfect for setting expectations at the start of development sessions.
prompts.example_output:
When working on a new feature, the AI will:
1. Break the work into modular components
2. Add comprehensive JSDoc documentation
3. Write tests for each component before moving on
4. Run tests to verify functionality
5. Only proceed after confirming everything works

This ensures high-quality, maintainable code from the start.

prompts.title: Extended Autonomous Coding Sprint
prompts.prompt_text: Your core guidelines are 1) prioritize modularity 2) focus on documentation and maintainability 3) always ensure we build testing as we go, and use it to confirm things work before we move on to the next thing. Your task is to get as far as possible without user input. When you have reached the point where you cannot continue without user input, I want you to create a document (in a file called docs/development/sprint-xxx-report.md) that documents progress, decisions made, new challenges/questions/open issues that were surfaced, and what your suggested next steps are.
prompts.description: Enable AI to work autonomously on complex tasks with clear documentation requirements. The AI works independently following best practices, then creates a comprehensive sprint report when it needs user input.
prompts.example_output:
The AI will autonomously:
1. Implement the feature with modular, tested code
2. Make architectural decisions and document them
3. Identify blockers and questions
4. Create sprint-001-report.md with:
   - What was accomplished
   - Decisions made and reasoning
   - Open questions requiring user input
   - Suggested next steps

This allows for extended autonomous work with full transparency.

prompts.title: GitHub Workflow Rules
prompts.prompt_text:
When we are working together, please follow these git workflow rules:

1. Commit liberally and often - Create git commits whenever you complete a logical unit of work (fixing a bug, adding a feature, refactoring a section, etc.)
2. NEVER push to GitHub without explicit permission - You may stage files (git add) and commit locally (git commit), but ONLY push to remote (git push) when I explicitly say "push to github" or similar.
3. Permission does NOT carry forward - If I say "commit and push" for one change, that permission applies ONLY to that specific commit. Future commits require NEW explicit permission to push.

Think of it as: Local commits are safe and encouraged. Remote pushes require explicit approval each time.

Understood?
prompts.description: Clear git workflow rules for AI coding assistants to prevent unauthorized pushes while encouraging frequent commits. Establishes safe defaults for version control collaboration.
prompts.example_output:
With these rules, the AI will:
- Commit after each feature/fix/refactor
- Never push without explicit "push to github" permission
- Ask for permission before each push
- Keep local commits frequent and well-organized

Example:
"I've completed the authentication feature and committed the changes locally. Would you like me to push to GitHub?"

This prevents accidental pushes while maintaining good git hygiene.

prompts.title: AI Context System Feedback
prompts.prompt_text: we are collecting feedback from real world use of the ai context system in order to improve it. can you please add your experience, documenting any bugs, suggestions and/or opportunities for improvement in context/context-feedback.md
prompts.description: Gather structured feedback from AI assistants about the AI Context System usage. Helps collect real-world insights for continuous improvement of development workflows.
prompts.example_output:
The AI will document:

## Feedback from Session 2025-11-25

### What Worked Well
- Context files provided clear project structure
- Session history helped maintain continuity
- Status tracking kept work organized

### Issues Encountered
- Template X could be clearer about Y
- Difficulty finding Z information

### Suggestions
- Add example for common use case A
- Improve documentation for B

This structured feedback drives system improvements.

prompts.title: TypeScript Build Check Before Push
prompts.prompt_text:
Before we commit and push, let's run a production build check to catch any TypeScript errors:

Run: cd apps/web && npm run build

If there are any TypeScript errors, show me the errors and fix them before we push to GitHub.
prompts.description: Ensure TypeScript code quality by running production builds before pushing. Catches type errors early and prevents broken code from reaching the repository.
prompts.example_output:
Before pushing, the AI will:

1. Run: npm run build
2. Check for TypeScript errors
3. If errors found:
   "Found 3 TypeScript errors:
   - src/components/Button.tsx:15 - Type 'string' is not assignable to type 'number'
   - src/utils/format.ts:42 - Property 'label' does not exist on type 'Item'
   
   Fixing these errors before pushing..."
4. Fix all errors
5. Re-run build to confirm
6. Only then push to GitHub

Prevents broken builds in CI/CD pipeline.

prompts.title: Development Server Port Management
prompts.prompt_text:
Before starting any dev server, always check for and kill existing processes on the target port
Never run multiple dev servers for the same project simultaneously - kill old ones before starting new ones
Use lsof -ti:[PORT] | xargs kill -9 to clean up ports before starting servers
Minimize background processes - only keep necessary dev servers running (one per active project)
When debugging, restart the existing server rather than spawning additional ones
If starting a new background process, verify no duplicate processes exist first
prompts.description: Essential guidelines for managing development server processes and ports. Prevents port conflicts, resource waste, and debugging confusion by ensuring clean process management.
prompts.example_output:
When starting a dev server, the AI will:

1. Check for existing processes: `lsof -ti:3000`
2. If found, kill them: `lsof -ti:3000 | xargs kill -9`
3. Start new server: `npm run dev`
4. Verify only one process running

This prevents:
- Port already in use errors
- Multiple servers consuming resources
- Confusion about which server is serving changes
- Zombie processes accumulating

Keeps development environment clean and predictable.

prompts.title: Product Requirements Document (PRD) Planning
prompts.prompt_text: I want you to come up with a plan for this project and save it as PRD-v1.md. Here are your guiding principles: you should design this process in small steps that can be completed and objectively tested independently. The system should be as modular as possible, should priortize professional design, maintainability, upgradability and performance. if you have any questions, you should ask them.
prompts.description: Generate comprehensive product requirements documents with emphasis on modularity, testability, and professional design. Creates structured planning documents that break complex projects into manageable steps.
prompts.example_output:
The AI will create PRD-v1.md with:

# Project Name PRD

## Overview
[Clear project description]

## Goals
1. Primary objectives
2. Success metrics

## Architecture
- Modular component breakdown
- Technology choices with reasoning

## Implementation Plan

### Phase 1: Foundation (Testable)
- Step 1.1: Setup
- Step 1.2: Core models
- Testing: Unit tests for models

### Phase 2: Features (Testable)
[Each phase independently testable]

## Questions
1. Preference for X vs Y?
2. Should we include feature Z?

Structured, actionable, and collaborative.

prompts.title: Modular Development Guidelines
prompts.prompt_text: Your core guidelines are 1) prioritize modularity 2) focus on documentation and maintainability 3) always ensure we build testing as we go, and use it to confirm things work before we move on to the next thing. I want you to commit liberally and often, but do not push to github without my permission.
prompts.description: Set clear development principles for AI coding assistants: modularity, documentation, testing, and git workflow.
prompts.example_output: The assistant will follow modular architecture, write comprehensive documentation, create tests before proceeding, and commit frequently while only pushing with explicit permission.

prompts.title: Git Workflow Rules for AI Assistants
prompts.prompt_text:
For this session, please follow these git workflow rules:

1. Commit liberally and often - Create git commits whenever you complete a logical unit of work (fixing a bug, adding a feature, refactoring a section, etc.)
2. NEVER push to GitHub without explicit permission - You may stage files (git add) and commit locally (git commit), but ONLY push to remote (git push) when I explicitly say "push to github" or similar.
3. Permission does NOT carry forward - If I say "commit and push" for one change, that permission applies ONLY to that specific commit. Future commits require NEW explicit permission to push.

Think of it as: Local commits are safe and encouraged. Remote pushes require explicit approval each time.

Understood?
prompts.description: Establish safe git practices for AI coding assistants with clear commit/push boundaries.
prompts.example_output: The assistant will commit frequently for logical units of work, but will never push to remote without explicit permission for each push.
